Hi friends I'm Rachna and I'm back with a
new lesson. Well, many times you may have

heard people tell you, you have to do this,
you've got to do this, okay. So, what does

it mean when someone tells you, you have to
this or you've got to do it. Well, that is

what we're going to learn in today's class-have
to and have got to. Well, both mean the same

thing and you can use them interchangeably.
Both mean an obligation.
Okay, so when you don't have a choice and you have to do something that you're told to do, it's your duty, you

really don't have a choice, that is the time
we say, you have to do this or you have got

to do it, Okay. So if I tell you, you have,
I have to study now, that means you have no

option and you have to do it. But remember,
after have to, you have an infinitive form

or the verb is in the base form. So don't
try using the past form. Don't say I have

to studied. You say I have to study now. It
is an obligation in the present tense. I can

also say, I've got to finish my project, okay.
Have got to is also an obligation in the present,

okay. So they can be used interchangeably,
both are correct. I have to study, I've got

to finish my project, okay. Now let's see
how we use it in the negative. When you put

have to in the negative, you say we don't
have to pay for the food. Now when I make

a sentence don't have to pay. First of all
remember, a lot people say I haven't, we haven't

to pay. This is wrong, okay, because have
to is the present tense, in the negative you

say, we don't have to or she doesn't have
to. Okay so you can say she doesn't have to

go. For he, she, it please remember you use
doesn't, okay. So now if I tell you, we don't

have to pay for the food, it means it is not
necessary, uh, there is no obligation to pay

for the food. So, we can, we cannot, either
which ways, it's okay. So we don't have to

pay. It is not necessary to pay. Okay, so
on a Saturday night if I tell you, you don't

have to do your homework today or tonight,
it means there is no compulsion, there is

no obligation. You could do it tomorrow. So,
you don't have to do it, okay. Now with a

structure have got to, uh using the negative
is not common. It's very uncommon way of saying,

but it is correct. We haven't got to pay for
the food. Now here you will not use don't

and doesn't, okay. So you put the negative
with haven't, have to make it haven't. We

haven't got to pay for the food. Well, this
is not incorrect, it is absolutely correct.

But, a very uncommon way of using it in the
negative. Generally, people prefer using this

structure,we don't have to do this, you don't
have to that. we haven't got to do it, you

haven't go to do that, is a very uncommon
way of saying it. But, it is correct. Okay,

so remember, there is a slight difference
when we use both these these structures in

the negative-have to you'll say don't have
to, she doesn't have to, okay. With have got

to you'll say, we haven't got to, you haven't
got to in the negative, okay. Now let's see

how do we use it in questions. Okay, do you
have to go to work tomorrow? That means, is

it compulsory, is it necessary for you to
go to work tomorrow? So either you use do

or does to make a question. Remember, if you
say does he have to work? Okay. So does he

have to. Don't make this common error, does
he has to? This is correct, incorrect. Does

he have to work? Is it necessary for him to
work? Is he obliged to work, okay. So when

you ask a question, you have a structure-do
you have to, does he have to with a question

mark. Now, when we use this structure in the
question, you say, have you got to go to work

tomorrow? See, it is the same as do you have
to? Only here, I have put have before the

subject you to form a question that says have
you got to go to work tomorrow? Well, this

is also correct, but again, a very less common
way of speaking. Okay, but you can use this

in the form of a question. Okay, now I have
a sentence here. You can't be serious! You've

got to be kidding. Now here, it does not,
you've got to be does not mean an obligation

that you have to be kidding. This is a certainty,
okay like you're quite sure. I mean, I'm sure

you're kidding. So when you talk about some
certainty, okay, you use, you've got to be

kidding. So, for example, there is a shirt
in my hand I say, uh, this has got to be your

shirt, it's not mine for sure., okay or this
is definitely not mine. It has got to be yours.

So, because I'm certain of what I'm saying,
I can say-you've got to be. But, you cannot

use that in case of have to. I can't say you
have to be kidding because there is no obligation.

But if i'm certain that uh I'm certain about
something I can say, you have got to be kidding.

This shirt has got to be yours, it's not mine
for sure, okay. So, remember this how we use

have got to be in case of certainty. Now let's
take a look at how these two structures are

used in different tenses. We have to leave
now. If i say, we have to leave now, this

is the present tense. Like I said, remember
to put this in the base or the infinitive

form. We have to leave now-present obligation.
You can also use have got to in the present

structure. We've got to leave now. That's
a present obligation, we've got to, we have

to, okay. If I put have to in the past tense,
it becomes we had to leave early yesterday.

I used yesterday, that's a past time period.
So definitely, I can;t say we have to leave

early yesterday, we had to. So, the past of
have is had. So, we had to leave early yesterday-

a past obligation. Well, with have got to,
you can never use the past tense because you

don't have a structure like we had got to
leave early yesterday, okay. Something like

this is completely incorrect. So with have
got to, when you want to talk about a past

obligation, it's best to use we had to, okay.
You cannot say we had got to. That's absolutely

incorrect. Now, in the future, I have a conditional
sentence here for you-If I don't go to university,

that means if I don't continue studying. If
I don't got to university, it's conditional

okay. There will be a consequence in the future
and the consequence is-I'll have to get a

job. That means I have no option, okay. I
mean i really have no option, it's an obligation

in the future outcome that will take place
in the future. So, I use will have to get

a job. I will have to get a job, if I don't
go to university. So well, we do use it with

will in the future, okay. Now, we can use
have got to for something that you refer to

the future, but remember, you do not use will,
okay. So you do not use will with have got

to.So, I tell you-I've got to call my mom
tomorrow. Tomorrow is the future, okay. So,

I'll put it in the present to talk about a
future action or something that I have planned

to do tomorrow. I've got to call my mom tomorrow.
I cannot say i will have got to call. So something

like this 
is completely incorrect. So, if you want to
talk about a future obligation using the structure,

keep it in the present. Well, you will have
an indication of a future time frame. In this

case it is tomorrow and then you can use it
in the future, but remember, do not use will,

okay friends. Well, this brings me to the
end of this lesson and I've got to go now.

So well, I have a test for you, take it and
do let me know your scores. I'll be back soon
with a new lesson, till then, take care and bye.
